oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Eddy Raven, the Kendalls, and T. Graham Brown Interviews - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Multiple recordings of interviews conducted by Biff Collie. First, is a recording of an interview with Eddy Raven (performer). Second, is a recording of an interview with the Kendalls (performance group). Last, is a recording of an interview with T. Graham Brown (performer).
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Eddy Raven; Biff Collie; the Kendalls; T. Graham Brown
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) "Zydeco Lady" is discussed by Eddy Raven as an idea he had with Troy Seals while working under a time constraint -- (01:10) Raven tells how he was a member of both RCA Studios and Universal Studios; Raven addressed how he was able to have artistic freedom while working with Universal Studios -- (02:30) Raven reflects on the musical career of Jimmy Bowen; this includes the various studios Bowen worked with -- (03:54) Raven talks about the meaning behind "Island" and Biff Collie jokes about the endurance of boats -- (04:33) Raven discusses "Little Sheba" and recalls how his son had helped Raven discover "Little Sheba" -- (05:50) Raven discusses the differences in his performance of "Little Sheba" compared to the original song-writer -- (06:27) Raven discusses Jimmy Bowen's gravitas and links Bowen to Raven's sound -- (07:37) Raven tells of a specific instance where Bowen helped craft a guitar chord -- (09:27) Collie and Raven reflect on how Raven stole "Sooner or Later" from the Forester Sisters -- (10:44) Raven tells of how he couldn't understand the "Sooner or Later" demo and required his son to interpret the lyrics -- (11:53) "Bayou Boys" is told by Raven as a song he almost gave to Alabama before he engaged in reworking the song -- (14:09) Raven recalls working for Roy Acuff and choosing "A Woman's Place" after Lee Greenwood passed on recording "A Woman's Place" -- (16:24) "Angel Fire" writer Mener Williams' talent is discussed -- (17:42)Raven reflects on the importance of Don Gant in getting Raven's writing career expanded and Gant's death -- (21:34) Collie and Raven praise the life of Gant -- (22:26) Collie and Raven laugh about Temporary Sanity and Raven reflects on the decisions made behind "Ricky Business" -- (23:09) Raven discusses how he's worked on a song titled "Temporary Sanity" but never released it -- (24:04) Royce Kendall reflects on how "Heaven's Just a Sin Away" appeared as the first track on 20 Favorites and Jeannie Kendall talks about recording early in the morning -- (25:53) "Love is a Long Hard Road" writer Curly Putman's efforts to get "Love is a Long Hard Road" recorded are discussed by the Kendalls -- (26:38) Jeannie tells about her inspiration for "Sweet Desire" and Royce tells of the day she revealed the song to him after a show -- (27:48) Jeannie praises "I'm Already Blue" writer Bob McDill -- (28:26) Collie jokes with the Kendalls about "If You Let Him Drive You Crazy (He Will)"; Jeannie and Royce reflected on the traditional nature of their album -- (29:23) Collie recaps the enormous size of the album -- (29:45) "Bye Bye Love" is talked about by Jeannie and Royce as a song that they had desired recording for quite some time -- (30:27) Royce and Jeannie recall visiting his publishing company and when they discovered " The Pittsburgh Stealers" before re-writing it -- (31:51) "Pick Me Up On Your Way Down" writer Harlan Howard is joked about, and the Kendalls recall the feelings associated with being introduced songs -- (32:34) R.J. Jones and Max Barnes' song "Thank God For The Radio" is discussed, and the Kendalls reflect on the song-producer's appreciation -- (33:54) "I'd Dance Every Dance With You" is reflected on as a song mainly brought in to the album to be a rare upbeat tune -- (34:22) "You'd Make an Angel Want To Cheat" is told by the Kendalls as a positive song about life -- (35:33) Collie and Jeannie talk about the meaning of the title "You'd Make an Angel Want To Cheat" -- (35:55) "Blue Blue Day" is described by the Kendalls as a song they instinctively knew would be successful -- (35:45) Royce tells of how he had began singing with his brother on the radio when he was six -- (37:40) Collie asks and Jeannie responds to the question of how Royce and Jeannie began singing together -- (39:29) "Just Like Real People" is touched on and Jeannie tells of how each song on the album are freshly cut -- (40:05) Jeannie retouches on "Just Like Real People" and the Kendalls reflect on how they had visited a set full of silver manikins -- (41:19) " Heartaches By The Number" is reflected on by Collie and the Kendalls as a great song that had not been recorded for quite some time -- (42:03) "I Had A Lovely Time" is discussed by the Kendalls and Collie as a track that had been recorded multiple times by the Kendalls -- (42:37) Collie tells a story of how he had worked with Lee Ross in California and Royce tells of when he worked with Ross on the California Hay Ride -- (43:35) Royce tells of how "Curtain in the Window" was originally a song Royce heard Ray Price perform -- (43:53) Jeannie reflects on her first time hearing "Curtain in the Window" and Jeannie and Royce reflect on how rare it was to hear on the radio -- (44:31) Collie and Royce reflect on Buck Owens being a part of Jeannie's first live performance; additionally, "Cryin' Time" was decided to be the song of Owens the Kendalls wanted to record -- (46:10) "It Don't Feel Like Sinnin' to Me" and the great writers on the album are touched on -- (46:37) The Kendalls reflect on "Once More," the piece has a described "blues feeling" -- (46:57) "Temporarily Out Of Order" writer Barnes is quickly reflected on for his contribution to the album -- (47:10) Royce and Jeannie show their appreciation for being allowed on the show -- (47:34) Collie asks T. Graham Brown about his outer influences in his country music, and Graham reflects on his authentic styling -- (49:41) Collie and Brown discuss how Brown will sometimes record a song "just because" including track "Hell or High Water" -- (51:02) Collie and Brown reflect on why Brown makes the decision to allow others to record his music -- (52:18) Brown tells of the demo songs he recorded that went on to become hit songs -- (53:03) Brown tells a story of how two of his friends from high school brought him a song called "1962" that was eventually recorded by Randy Travis as "1982" -- (54:35) Brown reflects on how recording demo tracks helped with his studio comfort -- (55:35) Collie and Brown describe the speed needed to work inside of a studio -- (57:04) Brown describes of the process of recording with a production company
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Kendalls (Musical group); Kendall, Jeannie; Raven, Eddy; Raven, Eddy, 1944-; Collie, Biff; Brown, T. Graham;
